subject: Re: mocking 3rd party classes?
msgSnippet: Dear Robert, Thank you for your quick answer. To inherit was my first guess also, but since the Message class has no default constructor the compiler does not
messageBody:
Dear Robert,
Thank you for your quick answer.

To inherit was my first guess also, but since the Message class has no
default constructor the compiler does not like:
class TestableMessage extends Message {
> public TestableMessage() {
> super(null);
> }
> }

The constructor message(null) is undefined.

regards,

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Koss" <koss@o...> wrote:
>
> >
> > I am working wiht a 3rd party api. Where I have to extend one
> > of their clases and Inteact via a receiveAsyncMessage(Message) method.
> >
> > The Message class ha no default or public constructor.
> >
> > class Message extends EventObject {
> > protected final String type;
> > /**
> > * some more properties
> > */
> > Message(String type,....){
> >
> > }
> >
> > }
> >
> > How can I mock this class?
> >
> > I want to be able to create fake messages to test my code
> > without having to run the server and the client application.
>
>
> Can you inherit from Message?
>
> class TestableMessage extends Message {
> public TestableMessage() {
> super(null);
> }
> }
>
>
>
> ---
> Robert S. Koss, Ph.D.
> Senior Consultant
> www.objectmentor.com
